comments.commentBody: Call it what it is --- Romneycare.
The Truth and Reconciliation process in South Africa, post Apartheid, specifically avoided prosecutions and prison but was not "nothing." Transparency alone is useful.

We, at least, need a debate on how we got to where we are, and how we redefine reasonable boundaries.

In the end, Lincoln did suspend habeas corpus during the civil war. However, it would seem that this particular problem is more related to political chicanery, and a 'retrospectively flawed, and probably ideologically driven' Supreme Court decision that put 'ideological purists with silver-bullet-thinking' in charge of the country.

"We, the people", aka the electorate is partly at fault, but the true error lies in our failure to reform Washington. This is not a 'big government problem'. It is a corrupt government problem, and although both parties are at fault, I would venture to say that a 'true' history will show that the corruption was engineered and driven by the 'party of money', and that too many of the members of the other party got dragged into the feeding frenzy, self aggrandizement, and self enrichment associated with 'mining' rather than building the country.

Transparency and "self examination" are quite useful and meaningful.

After Apartheid in South Africa, their Truth and Reconciliation process was fairly successful in "moving past it" without "prosecutions and prison."

"This act of self examination" means nothing if it is only to excuse ourselves for whatever we did.

It means something only if we do something about it.

That is why we can't "move past it" until we have dealt with it. That means prosecutions and prison. Until then, it is nothing.

You all must remember, Koreans are seeking to change the status quo. The ferry disaster shattered their trust.  Koreans are seeking accountability and screaming for it. As one of the best wired counties in the world, it will not be silenced. Those children did not die in vane. The Korean people will not forget.

Life is simply not smooth. We find all kinds of people in this world. Some people simply won't bother and some others make all kinds of gestures and even use abusive language to ridicule others for whatever reason.

It becomes extremely difficult to ignore the offending people. I simply don't understand what pleasure do they derive by ridiculing others but that's how it's and India is no exception either in this case.

The parents only need to tell the children that life is not simply smooth sailing but involves sailing in rough waters too.
I'm willing to chip in for the plane fare to get Cheney and Addelson to the Hague.
What kind of country expects other countries to clean up their mess for them? No, that's not the answer, either. It's our problem. We have to deal with it.

"[I]ndictments of Americans by other countries, or by international tribunals, must be expected" because our political system won't do it, probably can't do it.

The best thing now is to welcome and encourage that. Get it over with. And deliver the defendants, all of them, no exceptions.

No, it is not her airline, in fact as the article points out, her family owns 10%.  That said, if every airline VP on a departing flight sent their planes back to the departing  gates over something as trivial as Macadamia nuts, then there would be chaos at JFK and no flights would depart on time.  And did Ms. Cho wait for a replacement flight attendant to come on board as flight attendants are part of the safety crew for passengers.  Since the plane probably did not wait for a replacement, the plane was short one crew member.

I think you're confused. Obamacare is NOT a specific plan, it is a method of obtaining specific plans underwritten by private insurers (except for Medicaid plans). Blue Cross is one of those insurers (actually the main one in most states). If she went through a health care exchange, she would be referred to a list of plans that she could choose from. She would not be forced into any specific plan. Plus, Obamacare specifically mandates coverage of women's health care, including pregnancy, so this is clearly not correct. Also, referrals from Primary Care Physicians are standard practice for ALL HMO plans and have nothing to do with Obamacare. I think you've missed the point.

Another potential defendant writes that "it doesn't matter."

That is all the more reason to get prosecutions going ASAP.

I say she is a potential defendant, because this ought properly be done with a wide brush. It should cover those who ordered it, and those who encouraged and defended doing it, helped make it happen. As with Nurenburg, it must include the tainted political press too.
How would you know if the "vid" had been doctored?

WRONG. Don't let ideology get in the way of facts.
Everyone in the U.S has the right to protest. There are protests all over the country right now about the Garner and Brown incidents.

If the Macadamia were served incorrectly, Ms. Cho could have made an on the spot correction or counseled the flight attendant.  That is how training is normally done.  What if the plane were at 30,000 feet in the air, would she have thrown the flight attendant out of the plane or returned to JFK?  Maybe the flight attendant is lucky she did not spill wine on Ms. Cho.  Where does one draw the line when it comes to common sense?
This has nothing to do with a so-called "Ivy League style." You're pulling that out of thin air.
Indeed!
@SRW.    I flew Korean Air economy to Beijing.  The service was better than many of the business class flights that I have taken on other airlines--a whole lot better.
I'm hoping she will begin flying economy class and tightening up service there (not).

A member of the executive staff of this airline cancelled a flight over nut service, and after a righteous public outcry she resigned one of her responsibilities but not her position in this Korean fiefdom. I fear for the future of equality and for the responsibilities and accountability of management. It's time to make people accountable who get paid extremely well to perform but make huge blunders. There's always a place for you as a flight attendant, Cho.
And those in the media and universities and pyschiatric professions who had a role participating, encouraging, and excusing it.

You must be aiming to score merely partisan points like so many others in this debate. The warnings about al-Q'aeda's potential attacks were not limited to the Bush/Cheney administration, and thoughts about it had brewed since before Bush was even elected.

If you insist on pointing fingers at politicians--which is not out of the realm of reason--you need to acknowledge this is a plague on both parties and a national culture that had grown complacent over time.
"...liars,fools and opportunists running the nation" doesn't in any way excuse crimes committed by individuals further down the food chain.
@dtrimble: I'm not excusing the negligence under Clinton but the policy of overreaction to 911 obviously beagn under his successor.

Oh, come on, Mr. Friedman: the blame here rests not with the CIA "sentries" you refer to but rather with the administration under which they operated.  Who can doubt where their orders came from and what was expected of them, whether made explicit or merely implied?  Having ignored the warnings about al Qaeda's determination to use commercial airplanes to attack the U.S. and having allowed bin Laden to slip through their fingers in Tora Bora, Bush/Cheney would not allow further miscues to happen on their-ahem-"watch." Ergo the use of "enhanced interrogation," black prisons, renditions and, most egregious of all, a war declared against a country that hadn't attacked us the rationale for which was constructed out of thin air.  With liars, fools and opportunists running the nation can there be any wonder why individuals at the CIA acted as they did?
It's usually about the nose, but you're right.

"he'll precipitate a response that will not be fixable"

That means that Bush Admin already precipitated a response that is not fixable. No. It is fixable, and we must fix it.

That includes prosecutions and jail, not just to pay a price, but so they can't do it again and others won't dare.

Right now they are unchecked. That is the biggest problem.

Methinks the FAA needs to review this incident as to what emergency KL 86 had that required this flight to immediately return to JFK. Perhaps a sufficient fine and review of outstanding flight request approvals is in order-especially a sit-down with its domestic SkyTeam partner Delta as to what constitutes an emergency in American airspace.

Think about cancelling a flight over how the nuts were displayed, and tell me again how that could be justified.  There is value to attending to detail, but more so in knowing when it is worth inconveniencing a whole flight over a trivial issue, or dealing with the matter later after landing.
He has requested asylum.

So Ms. Cho resigns but remains vp with the airlines. That will teach her. I understand she will be teaching a class on anger management to other Cho family members as well as upper management. Has anyone heard what's happened to the chief flight attendant?

Well, if Cho is head of in-flight service, she should have been fired long ago if her attendants were serving nuts in plastic bags. She should have been the one to get thrown off the plane, not the chief flight attendant.

What they 'may have' done doesn't matter to me. I want the reporters to find out what they did do and put it in the story. And if the crew lied ('just reported a passenger being ill, or whatever'} to coddle an airline official, that's an important element of the story.

The shame was the doing of it. The so-called "security" agencies are nothing of the sort. They have seriously damaged our country's reputation. They have put us all at greater risk. We have dug a huge hole under our claim of moral superiority.
